channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: When Russian bombs fall on Kharkiv, this man collects the evidence
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Johnson, Anastacia Galouchka
item.description: This police investigator records the wreckage, measures the shrapnel and gathers the bodies, even without knowing if Russia will ever be held accountable.

item.title: Meta bans Russian state media outlet RT for acts of ‘foreign interference’
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih
item.description: The U.S. recently imposed sanctions on RT’s parent companies, Rossiya Segodnya and TV-Novosti, accusing them of acting as an arm of Moscow’s intelligence operations.

item.title: Suspected gunman’s search for Ukraine fighters was ‘no help,’ former volunteer says
item.dc:creator: David Stern, Annabelle Timsit
item.description: The Trump golf course suspect described himself as a defender of Ukraine and Taiwan. But a former representative of Ukraine’s International Legion said he was all talk.

item.title: Candidate hits opponent with chair during live TV debate
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy
item.description: José Luiz Datena slammed a chair into opponent Pablo Marçal at the São Paulo mayoral debate. Marçal’s aides said he was diagnosed with a fractured rib.

item.title: Death toll rises in European floods; more severe weather expected
item.dc:creator: Ben Brasch, Praveena Somasundaram, Kate Brady
item.description: At least 12 people have died in floods in central Europe, including in Romania, Poland, Austria and the Czech Republic, according to officials.

item.title: Gripped by despair, Israel’s hostage families try to keep hope alive
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason
item.description: “There is a rope hanging over my son’s head,” said Yehuda Cohen, father of hostage Nimrod Cohen. He says the U.S. must pressure Netanyahu into a cease-fire.

item.title: China frees U.S. pastor after nearly two decades, State Department says
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho
item.description: California pastor David Lin was charged with fraud by Chinese authorities while active in a religious movement. The United States says that he was wrongfully detained.

item.title: ‘Sprinkled with our blood’: Why so many Ukrainians resist land for peace
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel, Serhii Korolchuk
item.description: Ukraine is under pressure to cut a deal to end the war, especially if Trump wins, but these soldiers in the east are not ready to give up land.

item.title: Hunger still stalks Gaza
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: “I’ve never seen a crisis like this in my 25 years in humanitarian work,” a U.N. World Food Program regional director said of the increasingly insecure situation in Gaza.

item.title: Houthis fire missile from Yemen into central Israel, warn of more strikes
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason, Jennifer Hassan, Alon Rom , Niha Masih, Kareem Fahim
item.description: Israeli forces said the missile Sunday did not cause any direct injuries, but Netanyahu threatens, “we exact a heavy price for any attempt to harm us.”

item.title: 6 killed, thousands evacuated as storm batters Central and Eastern Europe
item.dc:creator: Praveena Somasundaram
item.description: Four died in Romania and one in Poland, and a firefighter in Austria was killed responding to floods. The storm is expected to linger over Europe for days.

item.title: Paris closes out its Olympic summer with dazzling Champions Parade
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: The Champions Parade for the Paris Olympic and Paralympic Games included a march down the Champs-Élysées and a medal ceremony led by President Emmanuel Macron.

item.title: Indigenous Colombian coca company challenges Coca-Cola’s trademark
item.dc:creator: María Luisa Paúl, Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Coca Nasa, the producer of Coca Pola, or coca beer, says it’s motivated by what it claims is bullying by the beverage giant.
